name: MCSB Ontology Test Data
description: Test data for the Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark Ontology following 60-20-10-10 distribution (typical/edge/boundary/invalid)

typical.description: Network Security covers controls to secure and protect networks, including securing virtual networks, establishing private connections, preventing and mitigating external attacks, and securing DNS.

Identity Management covers controls to establish a secure identity and access controls using identity and access management systems, including the use of single sign-on, strong authentications, managed identities for applications, conditional access, and account anomalies monitoring.

Privileged Access covers controls to protect privileged access to your tenant and resources, including a range of controls to protect your administrative model, administrative accounts, and privileged access workstations against deliberate and inadvertent risk.

edge.description: Governance and Strategy provides guidance for ensuring a coherent security strategy and documented governance approach to guide and sustain security assurance, including establishing roles and responsibilities for the different cloud security functions, unified technical strategy, and supporting policies and standards.

boundary.description: Endpoint Security covers controls in endpoint detection and response, including use of EDR and anti-malware service for endpoints in cloud environments.

typical.securityPrinciple: Ensure that your virtual network deployment aligns to your enterprise segmentation strategy defined in the GS-2 security control. Any workload that could incur higher risk for the organization should be in isolated virtual networks.

typical.controlName: Secure cloud native services with network controls
typical.recommendation: Secure cloud services by establishing a private access point for the resources
typical.securityPrinciple: Secure cloud services by establishing a private access point for the resources. You should also disable or restrict access from public network when possible.

typical.controlName: Use centralized identity and authentication system
typical.recommendation: Use a centralized identity and authentication system to govern your organization's identities and authentications for cloud and non-cloud resources
typical.securityPrinciple: Use a centralized identity and authentication system to govern your organization's identities and authentications for cloud and non-cloud resources.

edge.controlName: Define and implement multi-cloud security strategy
edge.recommendation: Define and implement multi-cloud security strategy
edge.securityPrinciple: Ensure a coherent multi-cloud security strategy that addresses security requirements across multiple cloud platforms including Azure, AWS, and GCP.

boundary.controlName: Ensure anti-malware software and signatures are updated
boundary.recommendation: Ensure anti-malware signatures are updated rapidly and consistently
boundary.securityPrinciple: Ensure anti-malware signatures are updated rapidly and consistently for the anti-malware solution. This is the minimum threshold control for endpoint security.

invalid._testNote: Invalid: controlId has invalid domain prefix, empty name/recommendation, principle too short, invalid domain reference

typical.guidanceText: Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks. Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address.
typical.implementationContext: Use Azure Virtual Network concepts and best practices. Consider application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration.

typical.guidanceText: Create a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your AWS network, so resources such as EC2 instances can be deployed into the VPC within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VPC for smaller sub-networks. For EC2 instances, use Security Groups as a stateful firewall to restrict traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address.
typical.implementationContext: At the VPC subnet level, use Network Access Control List (NACL) as a stateless firewall for explicit rules.

typical.guidanceText: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in Microsoft cloud resources, your organization's resources such as applications on Azure, and your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization.
typical.implementationContext: For Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.

edge.guidanceText: Implement a unified security strategy across Azure, AWS, and other cloud platforms. Use Microsoft Defender for Cloud to monitor and manage security posture across multiple cloud environments. Establish consistent identity, network, and data protection policies.
edge.implementationContext: Consider using Azure Arc for hybrid and multi-cloud management. Implement consistent security baselines across platforms.

boundary.guidanceText: Follow recommendations in Microsoft Defender for Cloud to keep all endpoints up to date with the latest signatures. Microsoft Antimalware and Microsoft Defender for Endpoint will automatically install the latest signatures and engine updates by default.
